images.name: 1_N
images.desc: The scenario when Rural Internship (henceforth called RI) was announced:_nl_So, most of us were interested in algorithmic programming and believed that being good at it will help to score you a good internship/placement. Also, after third semester substantial things had been taught and it was no doubt that December vacation was a nice time to build more skills in programming. _nl__nl_There was also a parallel thought going on in our collective mind, this was the only period were we as a group could have good time together. As the NGO list was announced we consulted some seniors and the second thought became strong and we selected HIFEED Uttarakhand as the place to go. But similar thoughts had crept in across the batch and there was huge demand-supply gap with HIFEED offering only 50 seats. We were fresh out of Economics course and thus we went on to quantify the gap. Groups sat near the E-ground router to discuss others’ preferences. Close to 80 people were our enemies. True numbers are unknown till date. Aayush, Aman and Ashutosh felt pretty confident since they had long foreseen the day and had practiced enough by booking tatkal tickets.

images.name: 2_N
images.desc: Fast Forward to the day when RI form was open - policy at our time was first come first serve and we were around 8-9 people seated in E-205 waiting for the form to arrive. We rushed through our lives to fill those forms. Adrenaline was so pumped, some of us were not even sure if we selected the correct NGO or wrongly anything else starting with 'H’. All of us except Devansh got selected in initial 50. We were excited as well as sad as Devansh wouldn’t be joining us on the fun journey that lied ahead. But Devansh was determined to come with us and successfully convinced our RI convener at that time that he possessed the skills and desire to do RI at HIFEED, which was granted to him after some talks with HIFEED (2 students were allowed exceptionally, Aashka and Devansh). Fun fact:  When the list of selected students for HIFEED arrived, there were some student who registered twice to be secure. That’s the reason why our poor Devansh couldn’t got a chance initially._nl__nl_This easily came down as one of our best decisions as group

images.name: 3_N
images.desc: So, the day came when around 40 of us were willing to travel to Uttarakhand to spend a month in the hilly village of Chamba. Some of our fellow mates have already reached HIFEED before us._nl_We began our around 22-hour long train journey from Vadodara to Haridwar at around 6:00 am. We all were very excited as it was our first train journey as a group.

images.name: 8_H
images.desc: Receiving marks on the journey was scary. But we even made fun out of it. Here is Rutul and Shrey displaying their Algebraic structures pointers and the difference of 1 shows in their experience. Don’t know how Ashutosh survived getting only 1 out of 10 in the subject.  P.S: Roshan and Devansh just survived that sem. Got 4 in EMT - They are not in the picture as they are busy partying hard! Roshan literally jumped of the bed in the chilly night just to party the 4 pointers!

images.name: 13_N
images.desc: We stayed at Haridwar for one night in the Gujarati Dharam Shala and planned to visit the Ghats of Ganga next day very early in the morning (around 4 AM) and then to Chamba._nl_For people visiting the ghats for first time it was a very pristine ad spiritual experience. Obviously, we took some pics. Aayush even took a holy bath. Then, we rushed back to the rooms to pick our luggage up and From Haridwar to Chamba we took a bus.

images.name: 14_V
images.desc: Stayed in Gujarati Bhavan in Haridwar. Really a budget option. Also, Roshan was also a part of Headrush, but these two identical beings (everything same) betrayed him by not telling him what they were going to wear - so Roshan showing his dissent by spoiling (read as making the pic lively) the pic. Also, Tirth patel trying to make them antelope.

images.name: 15_H
images.desc: 5 AM morning at Har ki Pauri. Spiritual group

images.name: 16_H
images.desc: Much sleepy middle row. The Domino Effect. r/AccidentalRenaissance ?

images.name: 17_N
images.desc: With so much of twists and turns in roads and in stomachs we reached Chamba. Some people suffered from motion sickness too especially due to the terrain.Then from Chamba, HIFEED was about 8 kms away and no buses would go that road, so we hired a car, to reach there. He left us at a sign marking HIFEED ahead. _nl__nl_HIFEED (Himalayan Institution for Environment Ecology Development) is an organization that focuses on improving the lives of mountain communities. You can find more information about it at hifeed.org. It is a 1- minute drive from Chamba to HIFEED. Entering HIFEED is tough when you have a trolley bag with you as from the main road it is a 200 m trek which in some places is only 10 cm wide. So, for the first time it was tough for us also. Somehow, we managed to reach there. We got a 12-bed dormitory room which for the next 3-4 weeks, became our funhouse. So, we were divided into 5 teams to work on specific problems related to local issues. Most of us were in the same group of Mitigating Disaster Management in hilly regions. So, we needed to study the communities and come up with a solution that can help them to understand various calamities and help them to attenuate the damages done by it.

images.name: 18_V
images.desc: We finally reach the place where RI starts. It said 200 meters more. But it was in terms of altitude and not like distance usually measured. Kaafi khun passina bahaya gaya uss din.

images.name: 19_N
images.desc: It is not a place where you continuously require to work on your project. In fact, we did various field trips to appreciate the nature.

images.name: 20_H
images.desc: This was the view from our stay during the RI. Beauty!

images.name: 21_N
images.desc: On the very first day, we made was 8.5 kms mountain trek which started from HIFEED, uphill to a temple and downhill to Chamba. We were late as no one was ready in the morning. So, the guide decided to start with whoever is present. So, we started running to catch the guide and colleagues before they got disappeared in the mountains but we were never able to find them. Instead we used technology to get going. Soon starting the late trip, we got divided into groups of 2-3 depending on the pace of the individuals. We communicated with the group ahead of us with the help of phones. Shrey was running last and soon gave up on the mountain trekking and headed back to HIFEED. Nisarg and Rutul were now running last but they did not lose hopes and were fast enough to catch Roshan and Aayush who were wandering on the road. As we travelled, we were got thirsty and found on a club on the road. Rutul dared to go inside and ask for the price of a water bottle. It was 60 Rs bottle and we decided dying of thirst would be better than purchasing the bottle so we continued the trekking by asking the directions from our preceding group. Shashank and Devansh – the two most fittest beings on the planet and consequently among us too were very well ahead in the lead. The roads were getting complicated as some of us were not sure whether we were going in the right directions. So, we asked Shashank and Devansh to wait for us. Luckily, we found them as by that time we were not knowing if it is the same mountain or not. Now we had enough manpower to find the hidden temple. But all we did was to follow Shashank as he had the instinct that it is the right direction. It was the right route and near to sunset, we reached the temple just to find out that the group had already begun descending the mountain from the other side. Now, we needed to reach Chamba from where jeep was ready to pick us up. In the meantime, we stopped at various places to click some pics as the views were beyond imagination. So, we reached Chamba just in the right time and we went back to HIFEED to call it a day.

images.name: 22_H
images.desc: This is how scenic the place was and we trekked 8 kms on the first day. One hell of a transformation from staying in beds awake till 4 AM in DA to waking up early and climbing hills.

Roshan completed LOTR marathon - an initiative that can be taken when you have lots of time in your hands. Although we were always at each other’s room at college too with E-205 being the hub after lectures and the place to stop by during meals, but this place made the bond much stronger.

images.name: 43_H
images.desc: Exhausted but Victorious.  It is a Pyrrhic Victory: A Pyrrhic victory is a victory that inflicts such a devastating toll on the victor that it is tantamount to defeat. Someone who wins a Pyrrhic victory has also taken a heavy toll that negates any true sense of achievement.

images.name: 44_N
images.desc: _nl_Tehri dam - A nearby attraction from Chamba is the city of Tehri and its famous Tehri Dam. So, taking around 20km of mountain road journey we reached Tehri Dam and the scene was amazing.  Unfortunately, we were denied entry into its campus due to some prior permission rule. We were at a height seeing the dam below us surrounded by mountains with water so clean. After getting a view of the Dam, we went to a nearby waterfront.

images.name: 53_N
images.desc: On, one of the days, we visited the Uttarakhand local milk factory. Nothing much was done there other than learning about the process of how milk is being pasteurized and how various products were made from milk and learning about the machines that were used.

images.name: 54_H
images.desc: Visited a center were women were sewing artifacts and selling them in the market. The whole process from raw material to selling done by them. Great demonstration of self-sufficiency, independence and empowerment. More Power to them!

images.name: 59_N
images.desc: We must have visited at least 10 villages nearby, some totally on foot by trekking and some half-way by jeeps. There we talked with the villagers and took a peep into their lifestyles along with fulfilling the aims of our respective projects. Cold climate, but very warm people.

images.name: 67_N
images.desc: After, we completed our respective projects and submitted the reports, we left HIFEED around the time of Christmas and straight away went to Mussoorie,  where after some hustle we found a hotel to stay at decent price and people divided themselves into smaller groups for the purpose of flexibility on how we were supposed to plan our travel. We all had to meet on 30th Dec at Haridwar from where our return was planned. Some of us booked AC tickets just for the luxury of it :D.  So, Nisarg, Shashank, Rutul, Devansh, Shrey and Roshan formed one group (henceforth called Sinister Six). Aayush, Ashutosh and Aman formed a trio. Aagam paired up Pratik, Kunjal and other girls.

images.name: 68_N
images.desc: For people visiting Mussoorie for the first time, it was a marvel. Beautiful place and people :p. We initially planned 2 days for Mussoorie but Sinister Six then extended their stay one day just to chill with no agenda.

images.name: 69_H

Sinister Six partnered up with a local Rickshaw and went to visit Buddhist Monastery, Robber’s cave and Shashtradhara at Tapkeshwar Mahadev temple. Too much for a one-day trip. Took too many pictures worth next 2-years profile pics.

Every other group after from Sinister Six visited earlier as they were running a day ahead. 4 from the sinister six still took the risk and wrapped Rishikesh by 4 in the evening.
